title: PART A: THESIS/CLAIM
stimulusHtml: To earn this point, the thesis must make a claim that responds to the prompt, rather than restating or rephrasing the prompt. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.
descriptions: The response does not respond to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The response responds to the prompt with a historically defensible thesis/claim that establishes a line of reasoning about the extent to which United States independence fostered change in the relationship between American Indians and American settlers in the period from 1763 to 1800. The thesis must consist of one or more sentences located in one place, either in the introduction or the conclusion.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples that earn this point include but are not limited to the following.

· “United States independence changed the relationship between American Indians and settlers a great deal because many American Indian nations lost the option of balancing European powers against each other in order to restrain White settlement.”

· “United States independence changed the relationship between American Indians and settlers a great deal because it removed the British government’s check on setters’ westward movement and led to new efforts by settlers to take Indian land.”

· “A relationship of conflict dating from the colonial period persisted between American Indians and American settlers throughout the period from 1763 to 1800.”

title: PART B: CONTEXTUALIZATION
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must describe broader historical events, developments, or processes that occur before, during, or continue after the time frame of the question that are relevant to the topic of the prompt. To earn this point, the context provided must be more than a phrase or a reference.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not describe a broader historical context relevant to the relationship between American Indians and American settlers in the period from 1763 to 1800.

The response describes a broader historical context relevant to the extent to which United States independence fostered change in the relationship between American Indians and American settlers in the period from 1763 to 1800.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of context might include the following, provided the essay clearly connects them to the prompt.

· Earlier alliances between some American Indian nations with the British and others with the French during the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries

· American settlers’ ongoing efforts to expand into the interior of North America

· International competition, trade, and alliance systems between American Indian nations and Europeans in North America

· Conflict and warfare between American Indians and European settlers in the seventeenth and eighteenth centuries

title: PART C1: EVIDENCE – PROVIDES EVIDENCE
stimulusHtml:
To earn one point, the response must identify at least two specific pieces of evidence relevant to the topic of the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not provide at least two specific historical examples of evidence relevant to the relationship between American Indians and American settlers in the period from 1763 to 1800.

The response provides at least two specific historical examples of evidence to the relationship between American Indians and American settlers in the period from 1763 to 1800.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary. Examples of evidence used might include the following.

· American Indian treaties and land sales

· Proclamation of 1763

· Pontiac’s Rebellion (1763–1764)

· Creek Indians

· Iroquois Confederacy

· Joseph Brant

· General Sullivan’s Expedition (1779)

· Treaty of Fort Stanwix (1784)

· Phelps and Gorham’s Purchase (1788)

· Northwest Territory

· American Indian confederacies

· General Anthony Wayne

· Battle of Fallen Timbers (1794)

· Treaty of Greenville (1795)

title: PART C2: EVIDENCE – USES EVIDENCE TO SUPPORT AN ARGUMENT
stimulusHtml:
To earn this point, the response must use at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence to support an argument in response to the prompt.

The course framework often allows teachers the flexibility to select their own examples when teaching the course content. As a result, responses may vary.
descriptions: The response does not support an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

The response supports an argument in response to the prompt using at least two pieces of specific and relevant evidence.

An example of evidence used to support an argument:

· “The Proclamation of 1763 was intended to limit American settlement west of the Appalachian Mountains. Settlers often moved past the line where settlement was barred and engaged in conflict with American Indians on the land that had been reserved for American Indians following their support for Britain in the Seven Years’ War.” (as part of an argument about westward migration)

· “The Northwest Ordinance of 1787 established the Northwest Territory, creating procedure for American settlers to organize communities and create states out of land largely held and occupied by American Indians.” (as part of an argument about organizing western territories)

· American Indian treaties and land sales
